Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Ken Lill wrote:
>>
[This clock problem with the data chip is] what made the=
 necessity of the Kludge PCB.
>>

For those that aren't familiar with the A=
strocade, they might think that Ken is referring to "kludge" in it's generi=
c sense, but he's not.  You can read more about Barry Ellerson's Kludge Boa=
rd, released in 1981, here:


http://www.ballyalley.com/documentation/misc_=
hardware_docs/misc_hardware_docs.html#KludgeBoardInstallationandModificatio=
nDoc

I think I actually have an unpopulated PCB of the kludge board in my =
collection... someplace.

>>
I've been actively looking to replace all of t=
he clock circuitry with something newer and more stable
>>

From this state=
ment, I take it that the clock problem with the data chip was never fixed i=
n any version of the Astrocade motherboard.  Does the clock issue destroy t=
he data chip, or does it "merely" make it not work properly?  From a user's=
 stand point, both Bally Arcade's would appear broken, but I presume that i=
f the issue is "just" the clock driver, then the data chip would still be o=
kay.  Maybe so many of these "dead" data chips aren't dead after all, but o=
nly appear dead.

I'm not clear what the problem is with the data chip's cl=
ock driver.  Ken, could you explain, in layman's terms, what is wrong with =
the clock that drives the data chip?

Adam

-------------------------------=
---------

From: ballyalley@yahoogroups.com <ballyalley@yahoogroups.com> on=
 behalf of ken lill kenzre@... [ballyalley] <ballyalley@yahoogroups.c=
om>
Sent: Tuesday, January 24, 2017 11:38 AM
To: ballyalley@yahoogroups.com=

Subject: Re: [ballyalley] Bally's 1979 Data Chip Clock Driver Fix

Tris wh=
at made the necessity of the Kludge PCB. The chip that did a level translat=
ion of the 5V oscillator and flip flop to a 10v P-P double clock for the Da=
ta chip was actually too slow and the rest of the clock  system was actuall=
y out of sync at times.
I've been actively looking to replace all of the cl=
ock circuitry with something newer and more stable, but as of yout, I can't=
 figure out a way to get the 7vP-P signal that is needed for the 10N transl=
ators  that are available.
Ken

----------------------------------------


=
From: "Adam Trionfo ballyalley@... [ballyalley]" <ballyalley@yahoog=
roups.com>

To: "ballyalley@yahoogroups.com" <ballyalley@yahoogroups.com>
S=
ent: Tuesday, January 24, 2017 2:12 PM
Subject: [ballyalley] Bally's 1979 D=
ata Chip Clock Driver Fix

This week, for the next episode of the Astrocast=
 podcast, Paul and I will be discussing several letters that were sent to t=
he Arcadian.  One letter, sent August 20, 1979, is from Jeff Frederiksen, t=
he chief engineer behind the design of the Bally Professional Arcade hardwa=
re. It seems that this letter was accompanied by some hardware.  The letter=
 simply states:

"The enclosed assemblies replace the 75361 clock driver, l=
ocated in the oscillator shield. The failure of the 75361 is that the 6V hi=
gh time after warm-up drops below 55ns causing the data chip to appear defe=
ctive. If you do not have this sinking clock syndrome,  replacement is not =
necessary. I hope you find the enclosed hardware description useful."

You =
can view the original letter here:


http://www.ballyalley.com/newsletters/=
arcadian/letters/letters.html#JeffFrederiksenLetterAugust201979

Bally Alle=
y - The Newsletter for Astrocade Users<http://www.ballyalley.com/newsletter=
s/arcadian/letters/letters.html#JeffFrederiksenLetterAugust201979>
www.ball=
yalley.com
Bally Astrocade newsletters, documentation, ads, letters, promot=
ional reading and manuals in pdf format, rare Astrocade hardware pictures, =
program downloads, and more Astrocade related material.


Unfortunately, th=
is is all the information this was included in the fabrics collection. Does=
 anybody know what Jeff is referring to here? Was this fix to the clock dri=
ver included on later releases of the Astrocade motherboard?

Adam

--_000_BLUPR16MB0387105E5FDF1D093D8CED4BC8750BLUPR16MB0387namp_

Ken Lill wrote:<br>
&g=
t;><br>
[This clock problem with the data chip is] what made the necessi=
ty of the Kludge PCB.
<br>
>><br>
<br>
For those that aren't familiar=
 with the Astrocade, they might think that Ken is referring to "kludge=
" in it's generic sense, but he's not.  You can read more about B=
arry Ellerson's Kludge Board, released in 1981, here:<br>
<br>
<p><a href=

e_docs.html#KludgeBoardInstallationandModificationDoc" class=3D"OWAAutoLink=

mentation/misc_hardware_docs/misc_hardware_docs.html#KludgeBoardInstallatio=
nandModificationDoc</a></p>
<br>
I think I actually have an unpopulated PCB=
 of the kludge board in my collection... someplace.<br>
<br>
>><br>
I=
've been actively looking to replace all of the clock circuitry with someth=
ing newer and more stable<br>
>><br>
<br>
From this statement, I take=
 it that the clock problem with the data chip was never fixed in any versio=
n of the Astrocade motherboard.  Does the clock issue destroy the data=
 chip, or does it "merely" make it not work properly?  From =
a user's stand point, both
 Bally Arcade's would appear broken, but I presu=
me that if the issue is "just" the clock driver, then the data ch=
ip would still be okay.  Maybe so many of these "dead" data =
chips aren't dead after all, but only appear dead.<br>
<br>
I'm not clear w=
hat the problem is with the data chip's clock driver.  Ken, could you =
explain, in layman's terms, what is wrong with the clock that drives the da=
ta chip?<br>
<br>
Adam<br>
